Description: Arsenical copper axe-head: with a convex cutting-edge, concave sides and two lugs. Previously thickly corroded, the blade has now been completely cleaned. It is severely pitted, and the cutting edge and lugs are damaged.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (?)
Curator's comments: Model of a plain blade axe, from a foundation deposit. Looks like it could be 18th Dynasty, in which case it was likely aquired and not originally from Naukratis(?). This simple form was produced since the Old Kingdom, and continued to be made in bronze and then iron for a considerable time (Petrie 1917, 9, Pl. v, A.135; 7). Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1917. Tools and weapons illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University college, London, and 2,000 outlines from other sources. London.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (130)
